description: From Middle English pen, penne (“enclosure for animals”), from Old English penn (“enclosure, fold, pen”), from Proto-Germanic *pennō, *pannijō (“pin, bolt, nail, tack”), from Proto-Indo-European *bend- (“pointed peg, nail, edge”). Related to pin.
Sense “prison” originally figurative extension to “enclosure for persons” (1845), later influenced by penitentiary (“prison”), being analyzed as an abbreviation (1884).

entries.meaning: An enclosure (enclosed area) used to contain domesticated animals, especially sheep or cattle.
examples: There are two steers in the third pen.

entries.meaning: (slang) Penitentiary, i.e. a state or federal prison for convicted felons.
examples: They caught him with a stolen horse, and he wound up in the pen again.
Two righties are up in the pen.

description: From Middle English pennen, from Old English *pennian (“to close, lock, bolt”, attested in onpennian (“to open”)), derived from penn (see above). Akin to Low German pennen (“to secure a door with a bolt”).

verbs.description: pen (third-person singular simple present pens, present participle penning, simple past and past participle penned or pent)

description: From Middle English penne, from Anglo-Norman penne, from Old French penne, from Latin penna (“feather”), from Proto-Indo-European *péth₂r̥ ~ pth₂én- (“feather, wing”), from *peth₂- (“to rush, fly”) (from which petition). Proto-Indo-European base also root of *petra-, from which Ancient Greek πτερόν (pterón, “wing”) (whence pterodactyl), Sanskrit पत्रम् (patram, “wing, feather”), Old Church Slavonic перо (pero, “pen”), Old Norse fjǫðr, Old English feðer (Modern English feather); note the /p/ → /f/ Germanic sound change.
See feather and πέτομαι (pétomai) for more.

entries.meaning: A tool, originally made from a feather but now usually a small tubular instrument, containing ink used to write or make marks.
examples: He took notes with a pen.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Marks of ink left by a pen.
examples: He's unhappy because he got pen on his new shirt.

entries.meaning: (zoology) The internal cartilage skeleton of a squid, shaped like a pen.
(now rare, poetic, dialectal) A feather, especially one of the flight feathers of a bird, angel etc.

verbs.description: pen (third-person singular simple present pens, present participle penning, simple past and past participle penned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To write (an article, a book, etc.).
